Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Utilizing Contextual Channel Characteristics for Secure Communications in Wireless Ad Hoc Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Bootstrapping security among devices is a crucial step for deploying wireless ad hoc networks in sensitive and mission-critical applications. Most existing solutions to security bootstrapping assume the existence of common resources such as additional hardware, auxiliary secure out-of-band (OOB) channels, or pre-existed trust among devices. In pervasive environments, however, these assumptions are not always practical. Given billions of available wireless devices nowadays, devices can be heterogeneous and highly diversified in hardware capabilities or user interfaces, and have limited common resources. This project conducts an exploratory study on bootstrapping security in wireless ad hoc networks without assuming any additional hardware, OOB channel or pre-existed trust. To this end, only physical-layer channel characteristics, which are automatically available to any wireless device, are used for security bootstrapping. Contextual factors such as device mobility and location are studied regarding their impacts on channel characteristics; algorithms for authenticated secret key establishment based on the contextual channel characteristics are designed; the effectiveness and efficiency of the security bootstrapping algorithms and techniques are evaluated through both theoretical analysis and experiments on a real testbed.

The success of this project provides a guideline on feasibility of utilizing channel characteristics for security bootstrapping in different ad hoc network contexts; the algorithms generated by this project provide extremely lightweight security bootstrapping solution that can be deployed on any commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) devices in pervasive environments. The research results of this project will be integrated into education, and disseminated in the forms of tutorials, talks, publications, and online software toolkit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proliferation of wireless devices has made it extremely convenient to deploy wireless networks in the ad hoc manner in pervasive environments. For trustworthy wireless communications, one fundamental issue is to bootstrap trust and establish initial secret keys among wireless devices at the early stage of network deployment. The lack of prior existing trust of wireless devices and their constrained computing resources and programming interface, however, cause essential challenges to the security bootstrapping of wireless networks. This project addresses these challenges by exploring contextual wireless channel characteristics for initial security bootstrapping and secret key extraction. Contextual information including mobility of the devices, human activities, geolocation, and the dynamics of surrounding environment are utilized for device authentication and secret key extraction. Both received signal strength (RSS) and channel state information (CSI) are explored for security bootstrapping. The PI implemented a test-bed for wireless body area networks and vehicular networks respectively. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of device authentication and a promising key generation rate based on the rich contextual wireless channel properties. The project has resulted in three published journal papers and one paper under submission. Four graduate students including two females and two undergraduate students participated in the project. The project also provided hands-on research experiences for a larger body of undergraduate students across the nation through the NSF REU program at the University of Arkansas at Little Rock.
